question: Are stretch enhancers transcribed more than super-enhancers?

Stretch enhancers are long-range enhancers that can be located up to 1 MB away from the promoter of a gene and can be transcribed themselves. Super-enhancers, on the other hand, are the largest and most active enhancer elements in the genome, typically found in developmentally regulated genes and often involved in cell-type-specific gene expression. The question asks whether stretch enhancers are transcribed more than super-enhancers. Based on the provided documents, there is no direct information comparing the transcription levels of stretch enhancers and super-enhancers. However, we can make an educated guess based on the understanding of the role of enhancers in regulating gene expression. Enhancers, including stretch enhancers and super-enhancers, are transcribed themselves and can regulate the transcription of nearby genes. Given that super-enhancers are often involved in cell-type-specific gene expression and are typically found in developmentally regulated genes, it is plausible that they may be transcribed more than stretch enhancers, which may have a more general regulatory function. Therefore, the answer is likely B. no.", "answer_choice": "B"}

snippets.content: Transcription regulators recognize short stretches of double-helical DNA of defined sequence called cis-regulatory sequences, and thereby determine which of the thousands of genes in a cell will be transcribed. Approximately 10% of the protein-coding genes in most organisms produce transcription regulators, and they control many features of cells. Although each of these transcription regulators has unique features, most bind to DNA as homodimers or heterodimers and recognize DNA through one of a small number of structural motifs. It often seems bewilderingly complex. Yet many of the same principles apply. As in bacteria, the time and place that each gene is to be transcribed is specified by its cis-regulatory sequences, which are “read” by the transcription regulators that bind to them. Once bound to DNA, positive transcription regulators (activators) help RNA polymerase begin transcribing genes, and negative regulators (repressors) block this from happening. In bacteria, as we have seen, most of the interactions between DNA-bound transcription regulators and RNA polymerases (whether they activate or repress transcription) are direct. In contrast, these interactions are almost always indirect in eukaryotes: many intermediate proteins, including the his-tones, act between the DNA-bound transcription regulator and RNA polymerase. snippets.content: How does a cell determine which of its thousands of genes to transcribe? Perhaps the most important concept, one that applies to all species on Earth, is based on a group of proteins known as transcription regulators. These proteins recognize specific sequences of DNA (typically 5–10 nucleotide pairs in length) that are often called cis-regulatory sequences, because they must be on the same chromosome (that is, in cis) to the genes they control. Transcription regulators bind to these sequences, which are dispersed throughout genomes, and this binding puts into motion a series of reactions that ultimately specify which genes are to be transcribed and at what rate. Approximately 10% of the protein-coding genes of most organisms are devoted to transcription regulators, making them one of the largest classes of proteins in the cell. snippets.content: Chromatin Can move to Specific Sites within the Nucleus to Alter gene Expression A variety of different types of experiments has led to the conclusion that the position of a gene in the interior of the nucleus changes when it becomes highly expressed. We will see in Chapter 6 that the initiation of transcription—the first step in gene expression—requires the assembly of over 100 proteins, and it makes sense that this would be facilitated in regions of the nucleus enriched in these proteins. More generally, it is clear that the nucleus is very heterogeneous, with functionally different regions to which portions of chromosomes can move as they are subjected to different biochemical processes—such as when their gene expression changes.
